Introduction
Title: Introduction to Markov decision processes
Markov decision processes (MDPs) are a class of discrete-time stochastic control processes with a very special structure that makes them amenable to simple analysis. Despite this special structure they have many applications, for example in reinforcement learning. We will start with carefully defining the Markov decision process and then prove two intuitive results — one of them by Blackwell (1964). Time permitting, we end with a brief discussion on connections with reinforcement learning.
Title: Basic results in Markov decision processes
We continue with our discussion from last time where we defined the Markov decision processes. We start with defining the notions of optimality and then discuss results when a policy is optimal.
Markov Decision Process
Markov decision processes (MDPs) are a class of discrete-time stochastic control processes with a very special structure that makes them amenable to simple analysis. Despite this special structure they have many applications, for example in reinforcement learning. This blog post isn’t about the applications though, but rather about the more technical existence and uniqueness questions — questions which are often ignored. We will start with carefully defining the Markov decision process and then show two intuitive results. We end with a brief discussion on connections with reinforcement learning.
In a Markov decision process there is an underlying discrete-time Markov process whose trajectory can be influenced by a decision maker by choosing actions from a pre-specified class of admissible actions. The goal is choose actions in such a way so as to optimize a performance criterion. The state of the system at time n+1n+1n+1﻿ then depends, in a Markovian way, on the state of the system and the action chosen at time n.n.n.﻿ Depending on how general the state spaces and action space are, this framework can model a wide variety of interesting problems.
Consider an inventory control problem. You are the manager of a distribution centre who sells the product to shops and buys the product in bulk from a factory. Suppose the maximum capacity of the distribution centre is CCC﻿ units, and therefore the state space is S=[0,C]S = [0, C]S=[0,C]﻿. The state of the distribution centre at time nnn﻿ is xnx_nxn​﻿ taking values in SSS﻿. The action that you can take is order some quantity of product from the factory. The action space AAA﻿ also equals [0,C][0,C][0,C]﻿. At time nnn﻿ you order ana_nan​﻿ from the factory. Of course, ana_nan​﻿ must take values in [0,xn][0, x_n][0,xn​]﻿. The demand from the shops is given by the i.i.d. random variables {ξn}n≥0\{\xi_n\}_{n \ge 0}{ξn​}n≥0​﻿ with common distribution μ.\mu.μ.﻿ It costs hhh﻿ dollars per unit of product to hold the product, bbb﻿ dollars per unit of product to buy the product, and earns sss﻿ dollars per unit of product to sell the product. Any unmet demand is simply lost revenue. How should you choose a policy π={an}\pi = \{a_n\}π={an​}﻿ to maximize the revenue over, say, NNN﻿ days?
Let us write the model more precisely. Suppose on day 000﻿ you start with x0x_0x0​﻿ units of product. Then we have
xn+1=max⁡{0,xn+an−ξn}=:f(xn,an,ξn),n≥0.x_{n+1} = \max\{0, x_{n}+a_{n}-\xi_{n}\} =: f(x_{n}, a_{n}, \xi_{n}), \quad n \ge 0.xn+1​=max{0,xn​+an​−ξn​}=:f(xn​,an​,ξn​),n≥0.
The revenue on day nnn﻿ is
rn=smin⁡{ξn,xn}−ban−hxn,n∈N.r_n = s \min\{\xi_n, x_n\} - b a_n - h x_n, \quad n \in \N.rn​=smin{ξn​,xn​}−ban​−hxn​,n∈N.
The total expected revenue is
JN(π,x0)=E[∑n=1Nrn].J_N(\pi, x_0) = \mathbb E \left[ \sum_{n=1}^N r_n \right].JN​(π,x0​)=E[n=1∑N​rn​].
Does there exist an admissible policy π∗\pi^*π∗﻿ such that it maximises the total expected revenue? That is,
JN(π∗,x0)=sup⁡πJN(π,x0).J_N(\pi^*, x_0) = \sup_{\pi} J_N(\pi, x_0).JN​(π∗,x0​)=πsup​JN​(π,x0​).
Is π∗\pi^*π∗﻿ optimal for every starting state x0x_0x0​﻿? It will be more convenient to model the transition dynamics of such a model using stochastic kernels, which informally model the transition probabilities of the process. That is, we want to find a stochastic kernel κ\kappaκ﻿ from S×AS \times AS×A﻿ to SSS﻿ which gives the probability of the state at day nnn﻿ being in B⊂SB \subset SB⊂S﻿ given that on day n−1n-1n−1﻿ the state was x=xn−1x=x_{n-1}x=xn−1​﻿ and we took action a=an−1a=a_{n-1}a=an−1​﻿. We can do this as follows
κ((x,a),B)=μ({s∈S∣f(x,a,s)∈B}).\kappa((x,a), B) = \mu(\{s \in S \mid f(x,a,s) \in B\}).κ((x,a),B)=μ({s∈S∣f(x,a,s)∈B}).
We haven’t been precise about our formulation. To this end, let us start by defining the objects like stochastic kernels and sets which will define our action and state spaces.
Setting the Stage
Stochastic Kernels
Suppose that a particle is moving randomly in a state space given by a measurable space (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿. We would like to be able to know the probability, denoted with say κ(x,B)\kappa(x, B)κ(x,B)﻿, of the particle finding itself in a set B∈SB \in \mathscr{S}B∈S﻿ given that it started at state x∈S.x \in \mathcal S.x∈S.﻿ Stochastic kernels model this notion of transition probabilities in a natural manner and we will rely heavily on them in our discussion.
Definition 1: Let (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ and (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ be two measurable spaces. A map
κ ⁣:S×T→[0,1]\begin{equation*} \kappa \colon \mathcal S \times \mathscr{T} \to [0,1] \end{equation*}κ:S×T→[0,1]​
is called a stochastic kernel or a Markov kernel from (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ to (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ — or, briefly, from S\mathcal SS﻿ to T\mathcal TT﻿ — if
x↦κ(x,B)x \mapsto \kappa(x, B)x↦κ(x,B)﻿ is S−\mathscr{S}-S−﻿measurable for each B∈TB \in \mathscr{T}B∈T﻿, and
B↦κ(x,B)B \mapsto \kappa(x,B)B↦κ(x,B)﻿ is a probability measure on (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ for each x∈S.x \in \mathcal S.x∈S.﻿
If (T,T)=(S,S)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T}) = (\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(T,T)=(S,S)﻿, one simply says a kernel on (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ or on S\mathcal SS﻿. One can view the stochastic kernel κ\kappaκ﻿ as a measurable function from S\mathcal SS﻿ to the space P(T)\mathcal{P}(\mathcal T)P(T)﻿ of probability measures on (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿, where the σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra on P(T)\mathcal{P}(\mathcal T)P(T)﻿ is generated by all the integration maps μ↦∫Sf dμ\mu \mapsto \int_S f \, \mathrm{d}\muμ↦∫S​fdμ﻿ for all measurable f≥0f \ge 0f≥0﻿. For this reason, stochastic kernel are also called random probability measures. One can also view the stochastic kernel κ\kappaκ﻿ as a probabilistic generalization of the concept of function from S\mathcal SS﻿ to T\mathcal TT﻿: instead of associating with each x∈Sx \in \mathcal Sx∈S﻿ a specific value from T\mathcal TT﻿, one associates a probability distribution on T.\mathcal T.T.﻿
Examples
Given a measurable space (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿, the function
S×S∋(x,B)↦κ(x,B)={1if x∈B,0if x∈S∖B\mathcal S \times \mathscr{S} \ni (x,B) \mapsto \kappa(x,B) = \begin{cases} 1 &\text{if } x \in B, \\ 0 &\text{if } x \in \mathcal S \setminus B \end{cases}S×S∋(x,B)↦κ(x,B)={10​if x∈B,if x∈S∖B​
defines a stochastic kernel on (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿, called the unit kernel. For each x∈Sx \in \mathcal Sx∈S﻿, the measure B↦κ(x,B)B \mapsto \kappa(x,B)B↦κ(x,B)﻿ is the Dirac measure δx\delta_xδx​﻿ on (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ at x.x.x.﻿
Given two measurable spaces (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ and (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ and a measure μ\muμ﻿ on (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿, the function
S×T∋(x,B)↦κ(x,B)=μ(B)\mathcal S \times \mathscr{T} \ni (x,B) \mapsto \kappa(x, B) = \mu(B)S×T∋(x,B)↦κ(x,B)=μ(B)
defines a stochastic kernel from (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ to (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ which does not depend on x.x.x.﻿ Therefore, every measure can be seen as a special type of a stochastic kernel.
Consider the two measurable spaces (S={1,2,…,n},P(S))(\mathcal S = \{1, 2, \ldots, n\}, \mathfrak{P}(\mathcal S))(S={1,2,…,n},P(S))﻿ and (T={1,2,…,m},P(T))(\mathcal T = \{1, 2, \ldots, m\}, \mathfrak{P}(\mathcal T))(T={1,2,…,m},P(T))﻿ for two integers n,m∈Nn,m \in \Nn,m∈N﻿ and P(S)\mathfrak{P}(\mathcal S)P(S)﻿ denoting the power set of S.\mathcal S.S.﻿ Suppose we are given an n×mn \times mn×m﻿ matrix K\mathbf KK﻿ containing non-negative elements such that the sum along each row is 1.1.1.﻿ Then the function κ\kappaκ﻿ defined by
S×P(T)∋(i,B)↦κ(i,B):=∑j∈BKi,j\mathcal S \times \mathfrak{P}(\mathcal T) \ni (i,B) \mapsto \kappa(i, B) := \sum_{j \in B} \mathbf K_{i,j}S×P(T)∋(i,B)↦κ(i,B):=j∈B∑​Ki,j​
is a stochastic kernel from S\mathcal SS﻿ to T.\mathcal T.T.﻿ The case where S\mathcal SS﻿ or T\mathcal TT﻿ are countably infinite is similar.
Regular Conditional Distribution
Let (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb P)(Ω,F,P)﻿ be a probability space, G\mathscr GG﻿ be a sub-σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra of F\mathscr FF﻿, (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr S)(S,S)﻿ be a measurable space, and X ⁣:Ω→SX \colon \Omega \to \mathcal SX:Ω→S﻿ be a random element. Does there exist a stochastic kernel κX∣G\kappa_{X \mid \mathscr G}κX∣G​﻿ from (Ω,F)(\Omega, \mathscr F)(Ω,F)﻿ to (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr S)(S,S)﻿ such that
κX∣G(ω,B)=P[{X∈B}∣G](ω)\kappa_{X \mid \mathscr G}(\omega, B) = \mathbb P \left[ \{X \in B\} \mid \mathscr G \right](\omega)κX∣G​(ω,B)=P[{X∈B}∣G](ω)
for P\mathbb PP﻿-a.e. ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omegaω∈Ω﻿ and for all B∈SB \in \mathscr SB∈S﻿? It can be shown to exist if S\mathcal SS﻿ is a Borel space (we define Borel spaces ahead). For a proof, check Dudley’s book Real Analysis and Probability. In this case, we call κX∣G\kappa_{X \mid \mathscr G}κX∣G​﻿ a regular conditional distribution of XXX﻿ given G\mathscr GG﻿.
A property which immediately follows from the definition is
∫GκX∣G(ω,B) dP(ω)=∫G1B(X(ω)) dP(ω)=P(G∩{X∈B}),G∈G.(R1)\int_G \kappa_{X \mid \mathscr{G}}(\omega, B) \, \mathrm{d}\mathbb{P}(\omega) = \int_G \mathbf{1}_B(X(\omega))\, \mathrm{d}\mathbb{P}(\omega) = \mathbb{P}(G \cap \{X \in B\}), \quad G \in \mathscr{G}. \tag{R1}∫G​κX∣G​(ω,B)dP(ω)=∫G​1B​(X(ω))dP(ω)=P(G∩{X∈B}),G∈G.(R1)
In the special case where G=σ(Y)\mathscr G = \sigma(Y)G=σ(Y)﻿ for a random element Y ⁣:Ω→TY \colon \Omega \to \mathcal TY:Ω→T﻿ taking values in a measurable space (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿, the stochastic kernel κX∣Y ⁣:T×S→[0,1]\kappa_{X \mid Y} \colon \mathcal T \times \mathscr S \to [0,1]κX∣Y​:T×S→[0,1]﻿ defined by
κX∣Y(y,B):=P[{X∈B}∣Y=y]:=κX∣σ(Y)(Y−1(y),B):=gB(y)\kappa_{X\mid Y}(y, B) := \mathbb P \left[ \{X \in B\} \mid Y = y \right] := \kappa_{X \mid \sigma(Y)}(Y^{-1}(y), B) := g_B(y)κX∣Y​(y,B):=P[{X∈B}∣Y=y]:=κX∣σ(Y)​(Y−1(y),B):=gB​(y)
is called a regular conditional distribution of XXX﻿ given YYY﻿. Here we used the Dynkin factorization lemma to see that for fixed B∈SB \in \mathscr SB∈S﻿, there exists a T−\mathscr T-T−﻿measurable gB ⁣:T→[0,1]g_B \colon \mathcal T \to [0,1]gB​:T→[0,1]﻿ such that κX∣σ(Y)(⋅,B)=gB∘Y.\kappa_{X \mid \sigma(Y)}(\cdot, B) = g_B \circ Y.κX∣σ(Y)​(⋅,B)=gB​∘Y.﻿ Using this factorization and (R1) we have for G∈σ(Y)G \in \sigma(Y)G∈σ(Y)﻿,
∫GκX∣Y(Y(ω),B) dP(ω)=∫GgB(Y(ω)) dP(ω)=∫GκX∣σ(Y)(ω,B) dP(ω)=P(G∩{X∈B}).(R2)\begin{align*} \tag{R2} \int_G \kappa_{X\mid Y}(Y(\omega), B)\, \mathrm{d}\mathbb{P}(\omega) &= \int_G g_B(Y(\omega)) \, \mathrm{d}\mathbb{P}(\omega)\\ &= \int_G \kappa_{X \mid \sigma(Y)}(\omega, B)\, \mathrm{d}\mathbb{P}(\omega)\\ &= \mathbb{P}(G \cap \{X \in B \}). \end{align*}∫G​κX∣Y​(Y(ω),B)dP(ω)​=∫G​gB​(Y(ω))dP(ω)=∫G​κX∣σ(Y)​(ω,B)dP(ω)=P(G∩{X∈B}).​(R2)
This implies that
P[{X∈B}∣Y=Y(ω)]=P[{X∈B}∣Y](ω), for P-a.e. ω∈Ω.(R3)\mathbb P \left[ \{X \in B\} \mid Y = Y(\omega) \right] = \mathbb P \left[ \{X \in B\} \mid Y \right](\omega), \quad \text{ for } \mathbb P\text{-a.e. } \omega \in \Omega. \tag{R3}P[{X∈B}∣Y=Y(ω)]=P[{X∈B}∣Y](ω), for P-a.e. ω∈Ω.(R3)
Define the regular conditional expectation of XXX﻿ given YYY﻿ at yyy﻿ as
E[X∣Y=y]=g(y),(R4)\mathbb{E}[X \mid Y=y] = g(y), \tag{R4}E[X∣Y=y]=g(y),(R4)
where g ⁣:T→Rg \colon \mathcal T \to \Rg:T→R﻿ is a T−\mathscr T-T−﻿measurable function such that E[X∣Y]=g(Y).\mathbb{E}[X \mid Y] = g(Y).E[X∣Y]=g(Y).﻿ Clearly,
E[X∣Y=Y(ω)]=E[X∣Y](ω), for P-a.e. ω∈Ω.(R5)\mathbb{E}[X \mid Y=Y(\omega)] = \mathbb{E}[X \mid Y](\omega), \quad \text{ for } \mathbb P\text{-a.e. } \omega \in \Omega. \tag{R5}E[X∣Y=Y(ω)]=E[X∣Y](ω), for P-a.e. ω∈Ω.(R5)
On this note we discuss disintegrations, which will simplify our notation and proofs involving regular conditional distributions.
Disintegration
We discuss the notion of disintegration in a general setting first.
Definition: Let (S,S,λ)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S}, \lambda)(S,S,λ)﻿ be a measure space, with λ\lambdaλ﻿ being a σ\sigmaσ﻿-finite measure. Let (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr T)(T,T)﻿ be a measurable space, and T ⁣:S→TT \colon \mathcal S \to \mathcal TT:S→T﻿ a measurable map. Finally, let μ\muμ﻿ be a σ\sigmaσ﻿-finite measure on T.\mathscr{T}.T.﻿ We say that λ\lambdaλ﻿ has a disintegration {λt}t∈T\{\lambda_t\}_{t \in \mathcal T}{λt​}t∈T​﻿ with respect to TTT﻿ and μ\muμ﻿, or a (T,μ)(T, \mu)(T,μ)﻿-disintegration, if for each nonnegative measurable function f ⁣:S→[0,∞]f \colon \mathcal S \to [0, \infty]f:S→[0,∞]﻿,
λt\lambda_tλt​﻿ is a σ\sigmaσ﻿-finite measure on S\mathscr{S}S﻿ concentrated on {T=t}≡T−1(t)\{T = t\} \equiv T^{-1}(t){T=t}≡T−1(t)﻿, i.e., λt{T≠t}=0\lambda_t\{T \neq t\} = 0λt​{T=t}=0﻿, for μ\muμ﻿-a.e. t∈Tt \in \mathcal Tt∈T﻿;
t↦∫Sf dλtt \mapsto \int_{\mathcal S} f \,\mathrm{d}\lambda_tt↦∫S​fdλt​﻿ is measurable; and
we have disintegration of the form
∫Sf dλ=∫T(∫{T=t}f dλt) μ(dt).(D1)\int_{\mathcal S} f \, \mathrm{d}\lambda = \int_{\mathcal T} \left(\int_{\{T=t\}} f \, \mathrm{d} \lambda_t\right) \, \mu(\mathrm{d}t). \tag{D1}∫S​fdλ=∫T​(∫{T=t}​fdλt​)μ(dt).(D1)
When does such a structure exist? The next theorem says for the cases we will consider ahead, disintegrations exist.
Theorem: Let λ\lambdaλ﻿ be a σ\sigmaσ﻿-finite Radon measure on a metric space S\mathcal SS﻿, i.e., λ\lambdaλ﻿ is a Borel measure for which λ(K)<∞\lambda(K) < \inftyλ(K)<∞﻿ for each compact KKK﻿ and λ(B)=sup⁡K⊆Bλ(K)\lambda(B) = \sup_{K \subseteq B} \lambda(K)λ(B)=supK⊆B​λ(K)﻿, the supremum being taken over compact sets, for each Borel set B⊆S.B \subseteq \mathcal S.B⊆S.﻿ Let TTT﻿ be a measurable map from S\mathcal SS﻿ into the measurable space (T,T).(\mathcal T, \mathscr T).(T,T).﻿ Let μ\muμ﻿ be a σ\sigmaσ﻿-finite measure on T\mathscr{T}T﻿ that dominates the image measure T#λT_{\#} \lambdaT#​λ﻿ of λ\lambdaλ﻿ under the map T.T.T.﻿ Finally, assume that T\mathscr TT﻿ is countably generated and contains all the singletons {t}.\{t\}.{t}.﻿ Then λ\lambdaλ﻿ has a (T,μ)(T, \mu)(T,μ)﻿-disintegration {λt}t∈T.\{\lambda_t\}_{t \in \mathcal T}.{λt​}t∈T​.﻿ Moreover, the measures {λt}t∈T\{\lambda_t\}_{t \in \mathcal T}{λt​}t∈T​﻿ are uniquely determined in the sense that if {λt′}t∈T\{\lambda_t'\}_{t \in \mathcal T}{λt′​}t∈T​﻿ is another (T,μ)(T, \mu)(T,μ)﻿-disintegration, then μ{t∈T∣λt≠λt′}=0.\mu\{t \in \mathcal T \mid \lambda_t \neq \lambda_t'\} = 0.μ{t∈T∣λt​=λt′​}=0.﻿
Regular conditional distributions and disintegrations have a close relationship. If in the notation above, λ\lambdaλ﻿ and almost all the λt\lambda_tλt​﻿ are probability measures on S\mathscr SS﻿, and XXX﻿ is a λ\lambdaλ﻿-integrable random variable, then in the notation of (R4),
∫ΩX dλt=Eλ[X∣T=t],(D2)\int_\Omega X \, \mathrm{d}\lambda_t = \mathbb{E}^{\lambda}[X \mid T=t],\tag{D2}∫Ω​Xdλt​=Eλ[X∣T=t],(D2)
where Eλ\mathbb{E}^\lambdaEλ﻿ denotes the expectation operator for the probability measure λ.\lambda.λ.﻿
A special case of (D1) which will be very useful later is when S=S1×S2\mathcal S = \mathcal S_1 \times \mathcal S_2S=S1​×S2​﻿ is a product space endowed with the product σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra S=S1⊗S2\mathscr{S} = \mathscr{S}_1 \otimes \mathscr{S}_2S=S1​⊗S2​﻿, (T,T)=(S1,S1)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T}) = (\mathcal S_1, \mathscr{S}_1)(T,T)=(S1​,S1​)﻿, T ⁣:S1×S2→S1T \colon \mathcal S_1 \times \mathcal S_2 \to \mathcal S_1T:S1​×S2​→S1​﻿ is the canonical projection map, and μ=T#λ\mu = T_{\#}\lambdaμ=T#​λ﻿ is the marginal on (S2,S2).(\mathcal S_2, \mathscr{S}_2).(S2​,S2​).﻿ Then
∫S1×S2f(x,y)λ(dx,dy)=∫S1(∫S2f(x,y)λx(dy))μ(dx).(D3)\int_{\mathcal S_1 \times \mathcal S_2} f(x,y)\lambda(\mathrm{d}x,\mathrm{d} y) = \int_{\mathcal S_1} \left( \int_{\mathcal S_2} f(x,y) \lambda_x(\mathrm{d}y) \right) \mu(\mathrm{d}x). \tag{D3}∫S1​×S2​​f(x,y)λ(dx,dy)=∫S1​​(∫S2​​f(x,y)λx​(dy))μ(dx).(D3)
Borel Space
Very few meaningful statements can be made about Markov decision processes when we impose no regularity structure on the spaces involved and let them be any measurable spaces. This is where Borel spaces come in — powerful results can be concluded with this structure, and yet they are sufficiently general to be satisfying.
Polish Space
Definition 2: A Polish space is a separable, completely metrizable topological space.
Examples
Any countable set with the discrete topology is Polish. So, for example, {0,1}\{0,1\}{0,1}﻿, N\NN﻿ and Z\ZZ﻿ are Polish.
Rn\R^nRn﻿ with the usual topology is Polish, for each n∈N.n \in \N.n∈N.﻿
Any closed subspace of a Polish space is Polish.
The disjoint union of countably many Polish spaces is Polish.
The product of countably many Polish spaces is Polish.
All of these examples follow from elementary properties of metric spaces. So, for example, to show example 5, first show that the product of countably many separable metric spaces is itself separable using the definition of product topology, and then show that the product of countably many complete metric spaces is itself a complete metric space using the idea of the product metric and definition of Cauchy sequences.
Polish spaces are the probabilist’s favourite spaces to work with since a lot of spaces are Polish, while almost all results that hold in R\RR﻿ still hold in a Polish space. For example, if (X,dX)(X,d_X)(X,dX​)﻿ is a compact metric space and (Y,dY)(Y, d_Y)(Y,dY​)﻿ is Polish, then C(X,Y)C(X,Y)C(X,Y)﻿, the set of continuous functions from XXX﻿ to YYY﻿ with the uniform metric d(f,g)=sup⁡x∈XdY(f(x),g(y))d(f,g) = \sup_{x \in X} d_Y(f(x), g(y))d(f,g)=supx∈X​dY​(f(x),g(y))﻿, is Polish.
Borel Isomorphism
Recall the notion of isomorphism between algebraic objects or the notion of homeomorphism between topological spaces. Both these notions give a bijective correspondence between two objects that preserves the algebraic or the topological structure. In a similar spirit we have the notion of isomorphism between two measurable spaces.
Definition 3 [Isomorphism and Borel isomorphism]: Two measurable spaces (S,S)(\mathcal S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ and (T,T)(\mathcal T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ are called isomorphic iff there is a bijective function f ⁣:S→Tf \colon \mathcal S \to \mathcal Tf:S→T﻿ such that both fff﻿ and its inverse f−1f^{-1}f−1﻿ are measurable. The function fff﻿ is called an isomorphism. In the special case where S\mathcal SS﻿ and T\mathcal TT﻿ are metrizable spaces equipped with their Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebras and f ⁣:S→Tf \colon \mathcal S \to \mathcal Tf:S→T﻿ is an isomorphism, fff﻿ is called a Borel isomorphism, and S\mathcal SS﻿ and T\mathcal TT﻿ are called Borel isomorphic.
It is obvious from the definition that two countable metrizable spaces are Borel isomorphic if and only if they are of the same cardinality. For the uncountable case, it is not immediately obvious when two spaces are Borel isomorphic.
Definition 4 [Borel space]: A Borel space is a measurable space isomorphic to a Borel subset of a Polish space.
Proposition 1: Let S\mathcal SS﻿ be a metrizable topological space. Then S\mathcal SS﻿ is a Borel space if and only if S\mathcal SS﻿ is homeomorphic to a Borel subset of a Polish space.
Proposition 2: Two Borel spaces are Borel isomorphic if and only if they are of the same cardinality.
Proposition 3: For every infinite Borel subset S\mathcal SS﻿ of a Polish space, the cardinality of its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra B(S)\mathcal{B}(\mathcal S)B(S)﻿ is c.\mathfrak{c}.c.﻿
Proposition 4: A Borel subset of a Borel space is itself a Borel space.
Borel space vs standard Borel space. Is a Borel space always a Borel subset of a Polish space?
Examples
Every Polish space is a Borel space.
Let P(S)\mathcal{P}(\mathcal S)P(S)﻿ be the space of probability measures on a Borel space S.\mathcal S.S.﻿ If P(S)\mathcal{P}(\mathcal S)P(S)﻿ is endowed with the topology of weak convergence, then it is a Borel space. This fact becomes useful when dealing with partially observable MDPs. Here a standard approach is to transform them into an equivalent “completely observable” MDP (the one in Definition 5 ahead) with a larger state space, a space of probability measures.
We will dealing with Borel spaces ahead, and therefore if no σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebras are explicitly specified assume that we endow the spaces with their Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebras.
Markov Decision Process
Markov Decision Model
Let us state by defining the moving parts of a Markov decision process. Our model evolves through time such that we can observe the state of the model and take admissible actions at discrete times n=0,1,2,….n = 0, 1, 2, \ldots.n=0,1,2,….﻿ We will say n≥0n \ge 0n≥0﻿ to mean nnn﻿ is a non-negative integer.
State Space
We denote by Sn\mathcal{S}_nSn​﻿ the state space of the model at time n≥0.n \ge 0.n≥0.﻿ We will assume that for each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0﻿, Sn\mathcal{S}_nSn​﻿ is a Borel space endowed with its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra.
Action Space
We denote by An\mathcal A_nAn​﻿ the action space at time n≥0.n \ge 0.n≥0.﻿ This is the set from which possible actions can be chosen at time n.n.n.﻿ It is possible that the admissible actions at time nnn﻿ is a strict subset of An\mathcal A_nAn​﻿ depending on the state of the model. We will again assume that for each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0﻿, An\mathcal A_nAn​﻿ is a Borel space endowed with its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra.
Admissible Actions
For each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0﻿, we have a mapping
αn ⁣:Sn→P(An)\alpha_n \colon \mathcal S_n \to \mathfrak{P}(\mathcal A_n)αn​:Sn​→P(An​)
from the state space Sn\mathcal S_nSn​﻿ to the set P(An)\mathfrak{P}(\mathcal A_n)P(An​)﻿ of all subsets of the action space An\mathcal A_nAn​﻿, which assigns to each x∈Snx \in \mathcal S_nx∈Sn​﻿ the set αn(x)\alpha_n(x)αn​(x)﻿ of admissible actions. We will assume that
αn(x) is a measurable subset of An,∀  x∈Sn,n≥0.\alpha_n(x) \text{ is a measurable subset of } \mathcal A_n, \quad \forall \; x \in \mathcal S_n, n \ge 0.αn​(x) is a measurable subset of An​,∀x∈Sn​,n≥0.
We will also assume that
⟦αn⟧ is a product measurable subset of Sn×An,∀  n≥0,\llbracket\alpha_n\rrbracket \text{ is a product measurable subset of } \mathcal S_n \times \mathcal A_n, \quad \forall \; n \ge 0,[[αn​]] is a product measurable subset of Sn​×An​,∀n≥0,
and that
there exists a measurable fn ⁣:Sn→An such that ⟦fn⟧⊆⟦αn⟧,∀  n≥0.\text{there exists a measurable } f_n \colon \mathcal S_n \to \mathcal A_n \text{ such that } \llbracket f_n \rrbracket \subseteq \llbracket \alpha_n \rrbracket, \quad \forall \; n \ge 0.there exists a measurable fn​:Sn​→An​ such that [[fn​]]⊆[[αn​]],∀n≥0.
Here
⟦αn⟧:={(x,a)∈Sn×An∣a∈αn(x)}⟦fn⟧:={(x,a)∈Sn×An∣a=fn(x)}\begin{align*} \llbracket\alpha_n\rrbracket &:= \{(x,a) \in \mathcal S_n \times \mathcal A_n \mid a \in \alpha_n(x)\} \\ \llbracket f_n\rrbracket &:= \{(x,a) \in \mathcal S_n \times \mathcal A_n \mid a= f_n(x)\} \end{align*}[[αn​]][[fn​]]​:={(x,a)∈Sn​×An​∣a∈αn​(x)}:={(x,a)∈Sn​×An​∣a=fn​(x)}​
are called the graphs of αn\alpha_nαn​﻿ and fnf_nfn​﻿ respectively.
Transition Law
For each time n≥0n \ge 0n≥0﻿, we have a stochastic kernel
κn ⁣:⟦αn⟧×B(Sn+1)→[0,1]\kappa_n \colon \llbracket\alpha_n\rrbracket \times \mathcal{B}(\mathcal S_{n+1}) \to [0,1]κn​:[[αn​]]×B(Sn+1​)→[0,1]
from the graph ⟦αn⟧\llbracket\alpha_n\rrbracket[[αn​]]﻿ (endowed with the Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra on the subspace topology) to Sn+1\mathcal S_{n+1}Sn+1​﻿, called the transition law. Therefore, if at time nnn﻿ the model’s state is xnx_nxn​﻿ and we took an admissible action ana_nan​﻿, then the probability of finding the model in state BBB﻿ at time n+1n+1n+1﻿ is κ((xn,an),B)\kappa((x_n, a_n), B)κ((xn​,an​),B)﻿, where BBB﻿ is a measurable subset of Sn+1.\mathcal S_{n+1}.Sn+1​.﻿
Reward Function
For each time n≥0n \ge 0n≥0﻿, we have a measurable reward function
rn ⁣:⟦αn⟧×Sn+1→[−∞,∞).r_n \colon \llbracket \alpha_n \rrbracket \times \mathcal S_{n+1} \to [-\infty, \infty).rn​:[[αn​]]×Sn+1​→[−∞,∞).
For (xn,an)∈⟦αn⟧(x_n, a_n) \in \llbracket \alpha_n \rrbracket(xn​,an​)∈[[αn​]]﻿ and xn+1∈Sn+1x_{n+1} \in \mathcal S_{n+1}xn+1​∈Sn+1​﻿, rn((xn,an),xn+1)r_n((x_n, a_n), x_{n+1})rn​((xn​,an​),xn+1​)﻿ models the reward received at time nnn﻿ when at state xnx_nxn​﻿ the admissible action ana_nan​﻿ was taken and the system transitioned to state xn+1.x_{n+1}.xn+1​.﻿ Under many performance criteria, it will suffice to model the rewards using r‾n ⁣:⟦αn⟧→[−∞,∞)\overline r_n \colon \llbracket \alpha_n \rrbracket \to [-\infty, \infty)rn​:[[αn​]]→[−∞,∞)﻿ which we can get from rnr_nrn​﻿ (assuming appropriate integrability) using
r‾n(x,a)=∫Sn+1r((x,a),y)κ((x,a),dy).\overline r_n(x,a) = \int_{S_{n+1}} r((x,a),y) \kappa((x,a), \mathrm{d}y).rn​(x,a)=∫Sn+1​​r((x,a),y)κ((x,a),dy).
The sequence
{(Sn,An,αn,κn,rn)}n≥0\left\{\left(\mathcal S_n, \mathcal A_n, \alpha_n, \kappa_n, r_n\right)\right\}_{n \ge 0}{(Sn​,An​,αn​,κn​,rn​)}n≥0​
of tuples defined above is called the non-stationary Markov decision model. We can find an equivalent stationary Markov decision model (S,A,α,κ,r)(\mathcal S, \mathcal A, \alpha, \kappa, r)(S,A,α,κ,r)﻿ by a standard augmentation procedure which we discuss next.
Stationary Markov Decision Model
Define the tuple (S,A,α,κ,r)(\mathcal S, \mathcal A, \alpha, \kappa, r)(S,A,α,κ,r)﻿ as follows:
S:={(x,n)∣x∈Sn,n≥0},A:={(a,n)∣x∈An,n≥0},S∋(x,n)↦α((x,n)):={(a,t)∈A∣a∈αn(x)},κ(((x,n),(a,n)),{(b,n+1)∣b∈B}):=κn((x,a),B),B∈B(Sn+1),⟦α⟧×S∋(((x,n),(a,n)),(y,n+1))↦r(((x,n),(a,n)),(y,n+1))  :=rn((x,a),y).\begin{align*} \mathcal S &:= \{(x,n) \mid x \in \mathcal S_n, n \ge 0\},\\ \mathcal A &:= \{(a,n) \mid x \in \mathcal A_n, n \ge 0\},\\ \mathcal S \ni (x,n) \mapsto \alpha((x,n)) &:= \{(a,t) \in \mathcal A \mid a \in \alpha_n(x)\}, \\ \kappa(((x,n), (a,n)), \{(b,n+1) \mid b \in B\}) &:= \kappa_n((x,a), B), \quad B \in \mathcal{B}(\mathcal S_{n+1}), \\ \llbracket \alpha\rrbracket \times \mathcal S \ni (((x,n), (a,n)), (y,n+1)) &\mapsto r(((x,n), (a,n)), (y,n+1)) \\ &\quad \; := r_n((x,a), y). \end{align*}SAS∋(x,n)↦α((x,n))κ(((x,n),(a,n)),{(b,n+1)∣b∈B})[[α]]×S∋(((x,n),(a,n)),(y,n+1))​:={(x,n)∣x∈Sn​,n≥0},:={(a,n)∣x∈An​,n≥0},:={(a,t)∈A∣a∈αn​(x)},:=κn​((x,a),B),B∈B(Sn+1​),↦r(((x,n),(a,n)),(y,n+1)):=rn​((x,a),y).​
We will thus assume a stationary Markov decision model from now on.
Definition 5: A Markov decision model is a tuple
(S,A,α,κ,r)(\mathcal S, \mathcal A, \alpha, \kappa, r)(S,A,α,κ,r)
consisting of
the state space S\mathcal SS﻿ which is a Borel space;
the action space or the control space A\mathcal AA﻿ which is a Borel space;
the mapping α ⁣:S→P(A)\alpha \colon S \to \mathfrak{P}(\mathcal A)α:S→P(A)﻿ from the state space to the set of all subsets of the action space, which assigns to each x∈Sx \in \mathcal Sx∈S﻿ the set α(x)\alpha(x)α(x)﻿ of admissible actions satisfying the assumptions:
α(x) is a measurable subset of A,∀  x∈S,(A1)\alpha(x) \text{ is a measurable subset of } \mathcal A, \quad \forall \; x \in \mathcal S, \tag{A1}α(x) is a measurable subset of A,∀x∈S,(A1)
⟦α⟧ is a product measurable subset of S×A,(A2)\llbracket\alpha\rrbracket \text{ is a product measurable subset of } \mathcal S \times \mathcal A,\tag{A2}[[α]] is a product measurable subset of S×A,(A2)
there exists a measurable f ⁣:S→A such that ⟦f⟧⊆⟦α⟧;(A3)\text{there exists a measurable } f \colon \mathcal S \to \mathcal A \text{ such that } \llbracket f \rrbracket \subseteq \llbracket \alpha \rrbracket; \tag{A3}there exists a measurable f:S→A such that [[f]]⊆[[α]];(A3)
the stochastic kernel κ\kappaκ﻿ from the graph ⟦α⟧:={(x,a)∈S×A ∣ a∈α(x)}\llbracket \alpha \rrbracket := \left\{(x,a) \in \mathcal S \times \mathcal A \,\mid\, a \in \alpha(x)\right\}[[α]]:={(x,a)∈S×A∣a∈α(x)}﻿ of α\alphaα﻿ to S\mathcal SS﻿ called the transition law; and
the measurable reward function r ⁣:⟦α⟧×S→[−∞,∞).r \colon \llbracket \alpha \rrbracket \times \mathcal S \to [-\infty, \infty).r:[[α]]×S→[−∞,∞).﻿
Policy
A policy π={πn}n≥0\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0}π={πn​}n≥0​﻿ is a sequence of prescriptions πn\pi_nπn​﻿ that at time nnn﻿ gives a rule for selecting the action. πn\pi_nπn​﻿ can be a randomized procedure or a deterministic procedure; it can depend on the entire history of the model or only on the current state. Let us formalize this concept.
History
Definition 6: For each time n≥0n \ge 0n≥0﻿, define the space Hn\mathcal H_nHn​﻿ of admissible histories up to time nnn﻿ by H0=S\mathcal H_0 = \mathcal SH0​=S﻿, and
Hn=⟦α⟧n×S=⟦α⟧×Hn−1,n≥1.\mathcal H_n = \llbracket \alpha \rrbracket ^n \times \mathcal S = \llbracket \alpha \rrbracket \times \mathcal H_{n-1}, \quad n \ge 1.Hn​=[[α]]n×S=[[α]]×Hn−1​,n≥1.
An element hn∈Hnh_n \in \mathcal H_nhn​∈Hn​﻿ is of the form hn=(x0,a0,x1,a1,…,xn−1,an−1,xn).h_n = (x_0, a_0, x_1, a_1, \ldots, x_{n-1}, a_{n-1}, x_n).hn​=(x0​,a0​,x1​,a1​,…,xn−1​,an−1​,xn​).﻿
Definition 7: A policy π={πn}n≥0\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0}π={πn​}n≥0​﻿ is a sequence of stochastic kernels πn\pi_nπn​﻿ from Hn\mathcal H_nHn​﻿ to A\mathcal AA﻿ subject to the constraint
πn(hn,α(xn))=1,∀  hn∈Hn,n≥0.\pi_n(h_n, \alpha(x_n)) = 1, \quad \forall \; h_n \in \mathcal H_n, n \ge 0.πn​(hn​,α(xn​))=1,∀hn​∈Hn​,n≥0.
The set of all policies is denoted by Π.\Pi.Π.﻿
Classes of Policies
The largest class of policies we consider is Π\PiΠ﻿ defined above. If instead of using the entire history, the policy makes a decision using only the current state, then we get a Markov policy.
Definition 8: If a policy π={πn}n≥0∈Π\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0} \in \Piπ={πn​}n≥0​∈Π﻿ is such that for each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0﻿, there exists a stochastic kernel φn\varphi_nφn​﻿ from S\mathcal SS﻿ to A\mathcal AA﻿ such that
πn(hn,⋅)=φn(xn,⋅),∀  hn=(x0,a0,…,xn−1,an−1,xn)∈Hn,\pi_n(h_n, \cdot) = \varphi_n(x_n, \cdot), \quad \forall \; h_n = (x_0, a_0, \ldots, x_{n-1}, a_{n-1}, x_n) \in \mathcal H_n,πn​(hn​,⋅)=φn​(xn​,⋅),∀hn​=(x0​,a0​,…,xn−1​,an−1​,xn​)∈Hn​,
then π\piπ﻿ is called a Markov policy. We denote the set of all Markov policies by ΠM.\Pi_M.ΠM​.﻿
Even more simply, if our policy at each time doesn’t depend on the time but only on the current state, we get a stationary policy. A stationary policy is necessarily Markovian.
Definition 9: If a policy π={πn}n≥0∈Π\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0} \in \Piπ={πn​}n≥0​∈Π﻿ is such that there exists a stochastic kernel φ\varphiφ﻿ from S\mathcal SS﻿ to A\mathcal AA﻿ such that for each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0﻿,
πn(hn,⋅)=φ(xn,⋅),∀  hn=(x0,a0,…,xn−1,an−1,xn)∈Hn,\pi_n(h_n, \cdot) = \varphi(x_n, \cdot), \quad \forall \; h_n = (x_0, a_0, \ldots, x_{n-1}, a_{n-1}, x_n) \in \mathcal H_n,πn​(hn​,⋅)=φ(xn​,⋅),∀hn​=(x0​,a0​,…,xn−1​,an−1​,xn​)∈Hn​,
then π\piπ﻿ is called a stationary policy. We denote the set of all stationary policies by ΠS.\Pi_S.ΠS​.﻿
What about deterministic policies?
Definition 10: A policy f={fn}n≥0f = \{f_n\}_{n \ge 0}f={fn​}n≥0​﻿ is called a deterministic policy if it is a sequence of measurable functions fn ⁣:Hn→Af_n \colon \mathcal H_n \to \mathcal Afn​:Hn​→A﻿ such that fn(hn)∈α(xn)f_n(h_n) \in \alpha(x_n)fn​(hn​)∈α(xn​)﻿ for all hn∈Hnh_n \in \mathcal H_nhn​∈Hn​﻿ and n≥0.n \ge 0.n≥0.﻿ We denote the set of deterministic policies by ΠD.\Pi_D.ΠD​.﻿ Similar to definitions 8 and 9, we can define the class of deterministic Markov policies ΠDM\Pi_{DM}ΠDM​﻿ and deterministic stationary policies ΠDS.\Pi_{DS}.ΠDS​.﻿
The set Π\PiΠ﻿ contains these deterministic policies, as can be easily seen by observing that for the deterministic policy f={fn}n≥0f = \{f_n\}_{n \ge 0}f={fn​}n≥0​﻿ the corresponding policy π={πn}n≥0\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0}π={πn​}n≥0​﻿ is given by
πn(hn,B)=δfn(hn)(B),hn∈Hn,B∈B(A).\pi_n(h_n, B) = \delta_{f_n(h_n)}(B), \quad h_n \in \mathcal H_n, B \in \mathcal{B}(\mathcal A).πn​(hn​,B)=δfn​(hn​)​(B),hn​∈Hn​,B∈B(A).
We thus have the following inclusions:
ΠS⊆ΠM⊆Π,  ΠDS⊆ΠDM⊆ΠD⊆Π,  ΠDS⊆ΠS,  ΠDM⊆ΠM.\Pi_S \subseteq \Pi_{M} \subseteq \Pi, \; \Pi_{DS} \subseteq \Pi_{DM} \subseteq \Pi_{D} \subseteq \Pi, \; \Pi_{DS} \subseteq \Pi_{S}, \; \Pi_{DM} \subseteq \Pi_{M}.ΠS​⊆ΠM​⊆Π,ΠDS​⊆ΠDM​⊆ΠD​⊆Π,ΠDS​⊆ΠS​,ΠDM​⊆ΠM​.
Canonical Construction
A natural questions now arises:
❓
Given a Markov decision model (S,A,α,κ,r)(\mathcal S, \mathcal A, \alpha, \kappa, r)(S,A,α,κ,r)﻿, a policy π∈Π\pi \in \Piπ∈Π﻿ and a distribution ν\nuν﻿ on S\mathcal SS﻿, does there exist a probability space (Ω,F,Pνπ)(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb{P}_{\nu}^{\pi})(Ω,F,Pνπ​)﻿ and stochastic processes {Xn}n≥0\{X_n\}_{n \ge 0}{Xn​}n≥0​﻿ with values in S\mathcal SS﻿ and {An}n≥0\{A_n\}_{n \ge 0}{An​}n≥0​﻿ with values in A\mathcal AA﻿ on this probability space such that for any B∈B(S)B \in \mathcal{B}(\mathcal S)B∈B(S)﻿, C∈B(A)C \in \mathcal{B}(\mathcal A)C∈B(A)﻿, n≥0n \ge 0n≥0﻿, and hn=(x0,a0,…,xn−1,an−1,xn)∈Hnh_n = (x_0, a_0, \ldots, x_{n-1}, a_{n-1}, x_n) \in H_nhn​=(x0​,a0​,…,xn−1​,an−1​,xn​)∈Hn​﻿, we have
Pνπ{X0∈B}=ν(B),(C1)\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\{X_0 \in B\} = \nu(B), \tag{C1}Pνπ​{X0​∈B}=ν(B),(C1)
Pνπ({An∈C}∣X0=x0,A0=a0,…,An−1=an−1,Xn=xn)=πn(hn,C), and(C2)\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{A_n \in C\} \mid X_0 = x_0, A_0 = a_0, \ldots, A_{n-1}=a_{n-1}, X_n = x_n) = \pi_n(h_n, C), \text{ and} \tag{C2}Pνπ​({An​∈C}∣X0​=x0​,A0​=a0​,…,An−1​=an−1​,Xn​=xn​)=πn​(hn​,C), and(C2)
Pνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣X0=x0,A0=a0,…,Xn=xn,An=an)=κ((xn,an),B)?(C3)\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid X_0 = x_0, A_0 = a_0, \ldots, X_n = x_n, A_n = a_n) = \kappa((x_n, a_n), B)? \tag{C3}Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣X0​=x0​,A0​=a0​,…,Xn​=xn​,An​=an​)=κ((xn​,an​),B)?(C3)
The notation on the LHS of equations (C2) and (C3) is the regular conditional probability. Recall the section on Regular Conditional Distribution above.
The answer to our question is, of course, yes. At this point recall the Ionescu-Tulcea theorem:
Theorem 1 [Ionescu-Tuclea]: Let {En,En}n≥0\{\mathcal E_n, \mathscr{E}_n\}_{n \ge 0}{En​,En​}n≥0​﻿ be sequence of arbitrary measurable spaces. For each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0﻿, let ηn+1\eta_{n+1}ηn+1​﻿ be a stochastic kernel from (E0×⋯×En,E0⊗⋯⊗En)(\mathcal E_0\times \cdots \times \mathcal E_n, \mathscr{E}_0 \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathscr{E}_n)(E0​×⋯×En​,E0​⊗⋯⊗En​)﻿ to (En+1,En+1)(\mathcal E_{n+1}, \mathscr{E}_{n+1})(En+1​,En+1​)﻿. Finally, let μ\muμ﻿ be a probability measure on (E0,E0)(\mathcal E_{0}, \mathscr{E}_{0})(E0​,E0​)﻿. Then there exists a unique probability measure P\mathbb PP﻿ on the measurable space (E,E)=(E0×E1×⋯ ,E0⊗E1⊗⋯ )(\mathcal E, \mathscr{E}) = (\mathcal E_0\times \mathcal E_1\times \cdots, \mathscr{E}_0 \otimes \mathscr{E}_1 \otimes \cdots)(E,E)=(E0​×E1​×⋯,E0​⊗E1​⊗⋯)﻿ whose value on every cylinder set B=B0×⋯×Bm×Em+1×Em+2×⋯B = B_0 \times \cdots \times B_m \times \mathcal E_{m+1} \times \mathcal E_{m+2} \times \cdotsB=B0​×⋯×Bm​×Em+1​×Em+2​×⋯﻿ for all m≥0m \ge 0m≥0﻿, where Bi∈EiB_i \in \mathscr E_iBi​∈Ei​﻿ for i=0,…,mi = 0, \ldots, mi=0,…,m﻿, is given by
P(B)=∫B0μ(dx0)∫B1η1(x0,dx1)⋯∫Bmηm((x0,x1,…,xn−1),dxn).\mathbb P(B) = \int_{B_0} \mu(\mathrm{d}x_0) \int_{B_1} \eta_1(x_0, \mathrm{d}x_1)\cdots \int_{B_m} \eta_m((x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_{n-1}), \mathrm{d}x_n).P(B)=∫B0​​μ(dx0​)∫B1​​η1​(x0​,dx1​)⋯∫Bm​​ηm​((x0​,x1​,…,xn−1​),dxn​).
More generally, for any non-negative random variable ZZZ﻿ on (E,E)(\mathcal E, \mathscr{E})(E,E)﻿ which only depends on the coordinates up to some finite index m≥0m \ge 0m≥0﻿, we have
∫EZ dP=∫B0μ(dx0)∫B1η1(x0,dx1)⋯∫Bmηm((x0,x1,…,xn−1),dxn)Z(x0,…,xm).\int_{\mathcal E} Z \, \mathrm{d}\mathbb{P} = \int_{B_0} \mu(\mathrm{d}x_0) \int_{B_1} \eta_1(x_0, \mathrm{d}x_1)\cdots \int_{B_m} \eta_m((x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_{n-1}), \mathrm{d}x_n) Z(x_0, \ldots, x_m).∫E​ZdP=∫B0​​μ(dx0​)∫B1​​η1​(x0​,dx1​)⋯∫Bm​​ηm​((x0​,x1​,…,xn−1​),dxn​)Z(x0​,…,xm​).
To this end, define
Ω=(S×A)∞\Omega = (\mathcal S \times \mathcal A)^{\infty}Ω=(S×A)∞
and F\mathscr{F}F﻿ to be the product σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra on Ω\OmegaΩ﻿. The elements of Ω\OmegaΩ﻿ are of the form ω=(x0,a0,x1,a1,…).\omega = (x_0, a_0, x_1, a_1, \ldots).ω=(x0​,a0​,x1​,a1​,…).﻿ Comparing our formulation to the one in Theorem 1, we let E2n\mathcal E_{2n}E2n​﻿ correspond to S\mathcal SS﻿ and E2n+1\mathcal E_{2n+1}E2n+1​﻿ correspond to A\mathcal AA﻿ for each n≥0.n \ge 0.n≥0.﻿ We let μ\muμ﻿ correspond to ν.\nu.ν.﻿ We let η2n\eta_{2n}η2n​﻿ correspond to the stochastic kernel πn\pi_nπn​﻿ from (S×A)n×S(\mathcal S \times \mathcal A)^n \times \mathcal S(S×A)n×S﻿ to A\mathcal AA﻿, and we let η2n+1\eta_{2n+1}η2n+1​﻿ correspond to the stochastic kernel from (S×A)n+1(\mathcal S \times \mathcal A)^{n+1}(S×A)n+1﻿ to S\mathcal SS﻿ obtained from κ\kappaκ﻿, for each n≥0.n \ge 0.n≥0.﻿ More concretely,
η2n+1((x0,a0,…,xn,an),B):=κ((xn,an),B).\eta_{2n+1}((x_0, a_0, \ldots, x_n, a_n), B) := \kappa((x_n, a_n), B).η2n+1​((x0​,a0​,…,xn​,an​),B):=κ((xn​,an​),B).
Then Theorem 1 implies that there exists a probability space (Ω,F,Pνπ)(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb{P}_{\nu}^{\pi})(Ω,F,Pνπ​)﻿ satisfying (C1), (C2) and (C3), where we define the random variables {Xn}n≥0\{X_n\}_{n \ge 0}{Xn​}n≥0​﻿ and {An}n≥0\{A_n\}_{n \ge 0}{An​}n≥0​﻿ by the projection maps:
Ω∋ω=(x0,a0,x1,a1,…)↦Xn(ω):=xn∈SΩ∋ω=(x0,a0,x1,a1,…)↦An(ω):=an∈A.\begin{align*} \Omega \ni \omega = (x_0, a_0, x_1, a_1, \ldots)&\mapsto X_n(\omega) := x_n \in S \\ \Omega \ni \omega = (x_0, a_0, x_1, a_1, \ldots)&\mapsto A_n(\omega) := a_n \in A. \end{align*}Ω∋ω=(x0​,a0​,x1​,a1​,…)Ω∋ω=(x0​,a0​,x1​,a1​,…)​↦Xn​(ω):=xn​∈S↦An​(ω):=an​∈A.​
To condense notation define the sequence {Hn}n≥0\{H_n\}_{n \ge 0}{Hn​}n≥0​﻿ of random variables by
Ω∋ω=(x0,a0,x1,a1,…)↦Hn(ω):=(X0(ω),A0(ω),…,An−1(ω),Xn(ω))=(x0,a0,…,an−1,xn)∈Hn.\Omega \ni \omega = (x_0, a_0, x_1, a_1, \ldots) \mapsto H_n(\omega) := (X_0(\omega), A_0(\omega), \ldots, A_{n-1}(\omega), X_n(\omega)) = (x_0, a_0, \ldots, a_{n-1}, x_n) \in \mathcal H_n.Ω∋ω=(x0​,a0​,x1​,a1​,…)↦Hn​(ω):=(X0​(ω),A0​(ω),…,An−1​(ω),Xn​(ω))=(x0​,a0​,…,an−1​,xn​)∈Hn​.
This allows us to (C2) and (C3) as
Pνπ({An∈C}∣Hn=hn)=πn(hn,C),(C2)\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{A_n \in C\} \mid H_n = h_n) = \pi_n(h_n, C), \tag{C2}Pνπ​({An​∈C}∣Hn​=hn​)=πn​(hn​,C),(C2)
Pνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣Hn=hn,An=an)=κ((xn,an),B).(C3)\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid H_n = h_n, A_n = a_n) = \kappa((x_n, a_n), B). \tag{C3}Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣Hn​=hn​,An​=an​)=κ((xn​,an​),B).(C3)
Definition 11: The stochastic process (Ω,F,Pνπ,{Xn}n≥0)(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi, \{X_n\}_{n \ge 0})(Ω,F,Pνπ​,{Xn​}n≥0​)﻿ along with the initial distribution ν\nuν﻿ and policy π∈Π\pi \in \Piπ∈Π﻿ is called a Markov decision process.
Definition 12: We call {Xn}n≥0\{X_n\}_{n \ge 0}{Xn​}n≥0​﻿ the state process and {An}n≥0\{A_n\}_{n \ge 0}{An​}n≥0​﻿ the action process.
We denote by Eνπ\mathbb{E}_\nu^\piEνπ​﻿ the expectation operator with respect to the probability space (Ω,F,Pνπ).(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi).(Ω,F,Pνπ​).﻿ We also denote by P2n\mathbb{P}_{2n}P2n​﻿ the product probability measure on (S×A)n×S(\mathcal S \times \mathcal A)^n \times \mathcal S(S×A)n×S﻿ obtained from the product of ν,η0,η1…,η2n−1\nu, \eta_0, \eta_1 \ldots, \eta_{2n-1}ν,η0​,η1​…,η2n−1​﻿ obtained using Fubini’s theorem, and denote by P2n+1\mathbb{P}_{2n+1}P2n+1​﻿ the product probability measure on (S×A)n+1(\mathcal S \times \mathcal A)^{n+1}(S×A)n+1﻿ obtained from the product of ν,η0,η1…,η2n\nu, \eta_0, \eta_1 \ldots, \eta_{2n}ν,η0​,η1​…,η2n​﻿ obtained using Fubini’s theorem, for each n≥0.n \ge 0.n≥0.﻿ Note that P0\mathbb{P}_0P0​﻿ equals ν.\nu.ν.﻿
Markov Property
Although equation (C3) looks like a Markov condition, the process {Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​}﻿ may not be a Markov process because of the dependence on history through the action process. It seems intuitively plausible that if the policy is Markov, then the state process should also be Markov. We prove this now.
Notation: If φ\varphiφ﻿ is a stochastic kernel from S\mathcal SS﻿ to A\mathcal AA﻿, then for every x∈Sx \in \mathcal Sx∈S﻿,
r(x,φ):=∫Ar(x,a)φ(x,da), andκ((x,φ),⋅):=∫Aκ((x,a),⋅)φ(x,da).\begin{align*} r(x,\varphi) &:= \int_{\mathcal A} r(x,a) \varphi(x, \mathrm{d}a), \text{ and} \\ \kappa((x, \varphi), \cdot) &:= \int_{\mathcal A} \kappa((x,a), \cdot) \varphi(x, \mathrm{d}a). \end{align*}r(x,φ)κ((x,φ),⋅)​:=∫A​r(x,a)φ(x,da), and:=∫A​κ((x,a),⋅)φ(x,da).​
Theorem 2: Under the setting of Definition 11, but where the policy π={πn}n≥0∈ΠM\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0} \in \Pi_Mπ={πn​}n≥0​∈ΠM​﻿, the state process {Xn}n≥0\{X_n\}_{n \ge 0}{Xn​}n≥0​﻿ is a non-homogeneous Markov process with transition kernels {κ((⋅,πn),⋅)}n≥0\{\kappa((\cdot,\pi_n),\cdot)\}_{n \ge 0}{κ((⋅,πn​),⋅)}n≥0​﻿, i.e., for every B∈B(S)B \in \mathcal{B}(\mathcal S)B∈B(S)﻿ and n≥0n \ge 0n≥0﻿, almost surely
Pνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣X0=x0,X1=x1,…,Xn=xn)=κ((xn,πn),B)=Pνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣Xn=xn).(M1)\begin{align*} \tag{M1} &\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid X_0 = x_0, X_1 = x_1, \ldots, X_n = x_n) \\ &= \kappa((x_n, \pi_n), B) \\ &= \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid X_n = x_n). \end{align*}​Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣X0​=x0​,X1​=x1​,…,Xn​=xn​)=κ((xn​,πn​),B)=Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣Xn​=xn​).​(M1)
In particular, if π∈ΠS\pi \in \Pi_{S}π∈ΠS​﻿, then the state process is a homogeneous Markov process.
Proof:
Let us start by fixing any policy π={πn}n≥0∈Π\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0} \in \Piπ={πn​}n≥0​∈Π﻿ and any B∈B(S).B \in \mathcal{B}(\mathcal S).B∈B(S).﻿ Then Fubini’s theorem implies that
∫Hn×APνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣Hn=hn,An=an)P2n+1(d(hn,an))=∫Hn(∫APνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣Hn=hn,An=a)πn(hn,da))P2n(dhn)=:∫Hnf(hn)P2n(dhn),\begin{align*} & \int_{\mathcal H_n \times \mathcal A} \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid H_n = h_n, A_n = a_n) \mathbb{P}_{2n+1}(\mathrm{d}(h_n, a_n)) \\ &=\int_{\mathcal H_n}\left(\int_{\mathcal A}\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid H_n = h_n, A_n = a)\pi_n(h_n, \mathrm{d}a)\right)\mathbb{P}_{2n}(\mathrm{d}h_n) \\ &=:\int_{\mathcal H_n}f(h_n)\mathbb{P}_{2n}(\mathrm{d}h_n), \end{align*}​∫Hn​×A​Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣Hn​=hn​,An​=an​)P2n+1​(d(hn​,an​))=∫Hn​​(∫A​Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣Hn​=hn​,An​=a)πn​(hn​,da))P2n​(dhn​)=:∫Hn​​f(hn​)P2n​(dhn​),​
where f ⁣:Hn→Rf \colon \mathcal H_n \to \Rf:Hn​→R﻿ is a measurable and integrable function defined as above. Then (D2) implies that f(hn)=Pνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣Hn=hn)f(h_n) = \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid H_n = h_n)f(hn​)=Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣Hn​=hn​)﻿ almost surely. Then using (C3) we can write
Pνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣Hn=hn)=∫Aκ((xn,a),B)πn(hn,da).(1)\begin{align*} \tag{1} \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid H_n = h_n) = \int_A \kappa((x_n, a), B) \pi_n(h_n, \mathrm{d}a). \end{align*}Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣Hn​=hn​)=∫A​κ((xn​,a),B)πn​(hn​,da).​(1)
Now if π∈ΠM\pi \in \Pi_Mπ∈ΠM​﻿, then equation (1) becomes
Pνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣Hn=hn)=∫Aκ((xn,a),B)πn(xn,da)=κ((xn,πn),B).(2)\begin{align*}\tag{2} &\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid H_n = h_n) \\ &= \int_A \kappa((x_n, a), B) \pi_n(x_n, \mathrm{d}a) = \kappa((x_n, \pi_n), B). \end{align*}​Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣Hn​=hn​)=∫A​κ((xn​,a),B)πn​(xn​,da)=κ((xn​,πn​),B).​(2)
This says that Pνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣Hn)\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid H_n)Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣Hn​)﻿ is XnX_nXn​﻿-measurable. Tower rule, therefore, implies
Pνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣Hn)=Pνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣X0,X1,…,Xn)=Pνπ({Xn+1∈B}∣Xn).\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid H_n) = \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid X_0, X_1, \ldots, X_n) = \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi(\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid X_n).Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣Hn​)=Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣X0​,X1​,…,Xn​)=Pνπ​({Xn+1​∈B}∣Xn​).
which is what we wanted to show. □\square□﻿
Performance Criteria
We haven’t even defined what performance criterion we are optimizing for! Suppose we have the Markov decision process and a class ΠA\Pi_AΠA​﻿ of admissible policies, where ΠA\Pi_AΠA​﻿ could be Π\PiΠ﻿ or ΠDM\Pi_{DM}ΠDM​﻿ or any other class we discussed above. The performance criterion measures how “good” a policy is. There are two performance criteria which are common in the literature: expected total reward and the long-run average expected reward per unit time.
Expected Total Reward
Definition 13: Given an initial state x0=x∈Sx_0 = x \in \mathcal Sx0​=x∈S﻿, a policy π∈ΠA\pi \in \Pi_Aπ∈ΠA​﻿, and a discount factor β∈(0,1)\beta \in (0,1)β∈(0,1)﻿, the expected total reward is given by
J(π,x):=Exπ[∑n=0∞βnr(Xn,An,Xn+1)].J(\pi, x) := \mathbb{E}^\pi_{x}\left[ \sum_{n=0}^\infty \beta^n r(X_n, A_n, X_{n+1}) \right].J(π,x):=Exπ​[n=0∑∞​βnr(Xn​,An​,Xn+1​)].
Recall that Exπ\mathbb{E}_x^\piExπ​﻿ simply means Eδxπ.\mathbb{E}_{\delta_x}^\pi.Eδx​π​.﻿ In this setting it is usually assumed that the reward function rrr﻿ is bounded, so that J(π,x)J(\pi, x)J(π,x)﻿ is a bounded function. In this blog post we will be interested in finite horizon problem, i.e., there is a finite N∈NN \in \NN∈N﻿ such that the performance criterion is
J(π,x):=Exπ[∑n=0N−1r(Xn,An,Xn+1)+rN(XN)],J(\pi, x) := \mathbb{E}_x^\pi \left[ \sum_{n=0}^{N-1} r(X_n, A_n, X_{n+1}) + r_N(X_N) \right],J(π,x):=Exπ​[n=0∑N−1​r(Xn​,An​,Xn+1​)+rN​(XN​)],
with rN ⁣:S→[−∞,∞)r_N \colon \mathcal S \to [-\infty, \infty)rN​:S→[−∞,∞)﻿, a measurable function, denoting the terminal reward. We use J∗J^*J∗﻿ to denote the value function
J∗(x):=sup⁡π∈ΠAJ(π,x),x∈S.J^*(x) := \sup_{\pi \in \Pi_A} J(\pi, x), \quad x \in \mathcal S.J∗(x):=π∈ΠA​sup​J(π,x),x∈S.
The problem is to find (if it exists!) a policy π∗∈ΠA\pi^* \in \Pi_Aπ∗∈ΠA​﻿ such that
J(π∗,x)=J∗(x),∀  x∈S.J(\pi^*, x) = J^*(x), \quad \forall \; x \in \mathcal S.J(π∗,x)=J∗(x),∀x∈S.
Note that in this setting, because of the expectation, we can replace the reward function rrr﻿ by r‾\overline rr﻿:
r‾n(x,a)=∫Sn+1r((x,a),y)κ((x,a),dy).\overline r_n(x,a) = \int_{\mathcal S_{n+1}} r((x,a),y) \kappa((x,a), \mathrm{d}y).rn​(x,a)=∫Sn+1​​r((x,a),y)κ((x,a),dy).
Therefore, we will now just assume that the reward function rrr﻿ is of the form
r ⁣:⟦α⟧→[−∞,∞).r \colon \llbracket\alpha\rrbracket \to [-\infty, \infty).r:[[α]]→[−∞,∞).
Long-run Average Expected Reward
Definition 14: Given an initial state x0=x∈Sx_0 = x \in \mathcal Sx0​=x∈S﻿ and a policy π∈ΠA\pi \in \Pi_Aπ∈ΠA​﻿, the long-run average expected reward per unit time is given by
J(π,x):=lim inf⁡m→∞1mExπ[∑n=0mr(Xn,An,Xn+1)].J(\pi, x) := \liminf_{m \to \infty} \frac{1}{m} \mathbb{E}^\pi_{x}\left[ \sum_{n=0}^m r(X_n, A_n, X_{n+1}) \right].J(π,x):=m→∞liminf​m1​Exπ​[n=0∑m​r(Xn​,An​,Xn+1​)].
We could have taken lim sup⁡\limsuplimsup﻿, and both give different results, but the lim inf⁡\liminfliminf﻿ case is easier to handle. Intuitively, the lim inf⁡\liminfliminf﻿ case gives a more pessimistic picture, while the lim sup⁡\limsuplimsup﻿ gives a more optimistic picture.
Optimal Policy
Deterministic Markov Policy 1
Suppose that we are in the finite horizon with the expected total reward regime. Assume that the terminal reward is 000﻿ for simplicity, and that the
reward function r ⁣:S×A→R is bounded.(A4)\text{reward function } r \colon \mathcal S \times \mathcal A \to \R \text{ is bounded.} \tag{A4}reward function r:S×A→R is bounded.(A4)
As the notation suggests, we have also implicitly assumed that α(x)=A\alpha(x) = \mathcal Aα(x)=A﻿ for every x∈S.x \in \mathcal S.x∈S.﻿ In this setting we want to compare the classes ΠD\Pi_DΠD​﻿ and ΠDM\Pi_{DM}ΠDM​﻿ of policies. We claim that there is no loss of optimality in restricting attention to the smaller class ΠDM\Pi_{DM}ΠDM​﻿ of deterministic Markov policies. This is a surprising result! Policies in ΠD\Pi_DΠD​﻿ can depend on the entire history in a very complicated manner, and it is not clear why a deterministic Markov policy should be just as good. I came across this result in a blog post by Maxim Raginsky [6]. The key result which we will use is from a 1964 paper by David Blackwell [5]. We state this result without proof.
Theorem 3 [Blackwell]: Let S,T,\mathcal S,\mathcal T,S,T,﻿ and A\mathcal AA﻿ be Borel spaces, let Q\mathbb QQ﻿ be any probability measure on the product space S×T\mathcal S \times \mathcal TS×T﻿, and let R ⁣:S×A→RR \colon \mathcal S \times \mathcal A \to \RR:S×A→R﻿ be a bounded measurable reward function. Then for any measurable function g ⁣:S×T→Ag \colon \mathcal S \times \mathcal T \to \mathcal Ag:S×T→A﻿ there exists another measurable function f ⁣:S→Af \colon \mathcal S \to \mathcal Af:S→A﻿ such that
∫S×TR(x,f(x)) Q(dx,dy)≥∫S×TR(x,g(x,y)) Q(dx,dy).\int_{\mathcal S \times \mathcal T} R(x, f(x)) \, \mathbb{Q}(\mathrm{d}x, \mathrm{d}y) \ge \int_{\mathcal S \times \mathcal T} R(x, g(x,y))\, \mathbb{Q}(\mathrm{d}x, \mathrm{d}y).∫S×T​R(x,f(x))Q(dx,dy)≥∫S×T​R(x,g(x,y))Q(dx,dy).
Let us now state and prove our theorem. Instead of fixing an initial state xxx﻿ as above in the total expected reward function, we let the initial distribution be any probability measure ν.\nu.ν.﻿
Theorem 4: For any policy π∈ΠD\pi \in \Pi_Dπ∈ΠD​﻿, there exists a policy τ∈ΠDM\tau \in \Pi_{DM}τ∈ΠDM​﻿ such that J(τ)≥J(π).J(\tau) \ge J(\pi).J(τ)≥J(π).﻿
Here, J(π)J(\pi)J(π)﻿, of course, denotes
J(π):=Eνπ[∑n=0N−1r(Xn,An)].J(\pi) := \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ \sum_{n=0}^{N-1} r(X_n, A_n) \right].J(π):=Eνπ​[n=0∑N−1​r(Xn​,An​)].
Before we prove the theorem, let us establish two lemmas.
The first lemma states that the theorem holds true for N=2.N=2.N=2.﻿
Lemma 1: If N=2N=2N=2﻿, then for any policy π=(π0,π1)∈ΠD\pi = (\pi_0, \pi_1) \in \Pi_Dπ=(π0​,π1​)∈ΠD​﻿ there exists a policy τ=(τ0,τ1)∈ΠDM\tau = (\tau_0, \tau_1) \in \Pi_{DM}τ=(τ0​,τ1​)∈ΠDM​﻿ such that J(τ)≥J(π).J(\tau) \ge J(\pi).J(τ)≥J(π).﻿
Proof:
Writing J(π)J(\pi)J(π)﻿ explicitly,
J(π)=Eνπ[r(X0,π0(X0))]+Eνπ[r(X1,π1(X0,π0(X0),X1))],J(\pi) = \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_0, \pi_0(X_0)) \right] + \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_1, \pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right],J(π)=Eνπ​[r(X0​,π0​(X0​))]+Eνπ​[r(X1​,π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))],
we note that the first term of RHS does not depend on π1.\pi_1.π1​.﻿ Using Blackwell’s theorem for the second term, with S,A\mathcal S, \mathcal AS,A﻿ being the same, T=A×S\mathcal T=\mathcal A \times \mathcal ST=A×S﻿, g=π1g = \pi_1g=π1​﻿, Q\mathbb QQ﻿ being the product of ν\nuν﻿ with the kernel determined by the function π0\pi_0π0​﻿ and the kernel κ\kappaκ﻿, as noted in the section of Policy, and R=rR=rR=r﻿, we conclude that there exists a measurable function τ1 ⁣:S→A\tau_1 \colon \mathcal S \to \mathcal Aτ1​:S→A﻿ such that
Eντ[r(X1,τ1(X1))]≥Eνπ[r(X1,π1(X0,π0(X0),X1))].\mathbb{E}_\nu^\tau \left[ r(X_1,\tau_1(X_1)) \right] \ge \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_1, \pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right].Eντ​[r(X1​,τ1​(X1​))]≥Eνπ​[r(X1​,π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))].
The claim follows after noting that we can take τ0=π0.\tau_0 = \pi_0.τ0​=π0​.﻿ □\square□﻿
The next lemma states that when N=3N=3N=3﻿ and the last policy π2\pi_2π2​﻿ is Markov, then we can choose even the second policy to be Markov. More precisely,
Lemma 2: If N=3N=3N=3﻿ and π=(π0,π1,π2)∈ΠD\pi = (\pi_0, \pi_1, \pi_2) \in \Pi_Dπ=(π0​,π1​,π2​)∈ΠD​﻿ is such that π2 ⁣:S×A×S×A×S→A\pi_2 \colon \mathcal S \times \mathcal A \times \mathcal S \times \mathcal A \times \mathcal S \to \mathcal Aπ2​:S×A×S×A×S→A﻿ is constant except in the last argument S\mathcal SS﻿, then there is a policy τ∈ΠDM\tau \in \Pi_{DM}τ∈ΠDM​﻿ such that J(τ)≥J(π).J(\tau) \ge J(\pi).J(τ)≥J(π).﻿
Proof:
We let τ=(τ0,τ1,τ2)∈ΠDM\tau = (\tau_0, \tau_1, \tau_2) \in \Pi_{DM}τ=(τ0​,τ1​,τ2​)∈ΠDM​﻿ be such that τ0=π0\tau_0 = \pi_0τ0​=π0​﻿, τ2=π2\tau_2 = \pi_2τ2​=π2​﻿, and define τ1\tau_1τ1​﻿ as follows. Writing J(π)J(\pi)J(π)﻿ explicitly,
J(π)=Eνπ[r(X0,π0(X0))]+Eνπ[r(X1,π1(X0,π0(X0),X1))]+Eνπ[r(X2,π2(X2))],(3)J(\pi) = \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_0, \pi_0(X_0)) \right] + \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_1, \pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right] + \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_2, \pi_2(X_2)) \right], \tag{3}J(π)=Eνπ​[r(X0​,π0​(X0​))]+Eνπ​[r(X1​,π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))]+Eνπ​[r(X2​,π2​(X2​))],(3)
where we ignored the irrelevant terms in π2\pi_2π2​﻿, we note that the first term does not depend on π1\pi_1π1​﻿ and π2.\pi_2.π2​.﻿ Since X2X_2X2​﻿ depends on the action π1(X0,π0(X0),X1)\pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​)﻿ taken at time 111﻿, both the second and the third terms depend on π1.\pi_1.π1​.﻿
Focusing on the third term,
Eνπ[r(X2,π2(X2))]=Eνπ[Eνπ[r(X2,π2(X2))∣X1,A1]]=:Eνπ[h(X1,A1)].\mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_2, \pi_2(X_2)) \right] = \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[\mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_2, \pi_2(X_2)) \mid X_1, A_1 \right]\right] =: \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[h(X_1, A_1)\right].Eνπ​[r(X2​,π2​(X2​))]=Eνπ​[Eνπ​[r(X2​,π2​(X2​))∣X1​,A1​]]=:Eνπ​[h(X1​,A1​)].
Using (R5) and then (D2) we can write, almost surely,
h(x1,a1)=Eνπ[r(X2,π2(X2))∣X1=x1,A1=a1]=∫Sr(x2,π2(x2))κ((x1,a1),dx2).\begin{align*} h(x_1, a_1) &= \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_2, \pi_2(X_2)) \mid X_1=x_1, A_1=a_1 \right] \\ &= \int_{\mathcal S} r(x_2, \pi_2(x_2)) \kappa((x_1, a_1), \mathrm{d}x_2). \end{align*}h(x1​,a1​)​=Eνπ​[r(X2​,π2​(X2​))∣X1​=x1​,A1​=a1​]=∫S​r(x2​,π2​(x2​))κ((x1​,a1​),dx2​).​
Then the function hhh﻿ is measurable and bounded. Now define
R(x,a)=r(x,a)+h(x,a),R(x,a) = r(x,a) + h(x,a),R(x,a)=r(x,a)+h(x,a),
which is also measurable and bounded, and note that by combining the previous results we can write the last two two terms of RHS of (3) as
Eνπ[r(X1,π1(X0,π0(X0),X1))]+Eνπ[r(X2,π2(X2))]=Eνπ[R(X1,π1(X0,π0(X0),X1))].\mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_1, \pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right] + \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_2, \pi_2(X_2)) \right] = \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ R(X_1, \pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right].Eνπ​[r(X1​,π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))]+Eνπ​[r(X2​,π2​(X2​))]=Eνπ​[R(X1​,π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))].
Applying Blackwell’s theorem, with S,A,R\mathcal S, \mathcal A, RS,A,R﻿ being the same, T=A×S\mathcal T=\mathcal A \times \mathcal ST=A×S﻿, g=π1g = \pi_1g=π1​﻿, Q\mathbb QQ﻿ being the product of ν\nuν﻿ with the kernel determined by the function π0\pi_0π0​﻿ and the kernel κ\kappaκ﻿, as noted in the section of Policy, we conclude that there exists a measurable function τ1 ⁣:S→A\tau_1 \colon \mathcal S \to \mathcal Aτ1​:S→A﻿ such that
Eντ[R(X1,τ1(X1))]≥Eνπ[R(X1,π1(X0,π0(X0),X1))].\mathbb{E}_\nu^\tau \left[ R(X_1,\tau_1(X_1)) \right] \ge \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ R(X_1, \pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right].Eντ​[R(X1​,τ1​(X1​))]≥Eνπ​[R(X1​,π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))].
But note that we can write
Eντ[R(X1,τ1(X1))]=Eντ[r(X1,τ1(X0,π0(X0),X1))]+Eνπ[r(X2,τ2(X2))],\mathbb{E}_\nu^\tau \left[ R(X_1,\tau_1(X_1)) \right] = \mathbb{E}_\nu^\tau \left[ r(X_1, \tau_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right] + \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_2, \tau_2(X_2)) \right],Eντ​[R(X1​,τ1​(X1​))]=Eντ​[r(X1​,τ1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))]+Eνπ​[r(X2​,τ2​(X2​))],
and thus J(τ)≥J(π)J(\tau) \ge J(\pi)J(τ)≥J(π)﻿ and the lemma is proved. □\square□﻿
Finally, we come to the proof of Theorem 4.
Proof of Theorem 4:
Let π∈ΠD.\pi \in \Pi_D.π∈ΠD​.﻿ The cases N=1N=1N=1﻿ and N=2N=2N=2﻿ follow from the lemmas. For N≥3N \ge 3N≥3﻿ we analyze as follows:
View π\piπ﻿ as a two-step policy ((π0,…,πN−2),πN−1)((\pi_0, \ldots, \pi_{N-2}), \pi_{N-1})((π0​,…,πN−2​),πN−1​)﻿ in an alternative two-step MDP. Then by Lemma 1, we can assume that πN−1\pi_{N-1}πN−1​﻿ is a Markov policy.
Now view π\piπ﻿ as a three-step policy ((π0,…,πN−3),πN−2,πN−1)((\pi_0, \ldots, \pi_{N-3}), \pi_{N-2}, \pi_{N-1})((π0​,…,πN−3​),πN−2​,πN−1​)﻿. The policy in the third time-step πN−1\pi_{N-1}πN−1​﻿ is Markov, and so we can apply Lemma 2 to conclude that πN−2\pi_{N-2}πN−2​﻿ is also Markov.
We continue in a similar manner for smaller indices k=N−3,N−4,…k = N-3, N-4, \ldotsk=N−3,N−4,…﻿ to get our result. □\square□﻿
Deterministic Markov Policy 2
When can we say that there exists an optimal policy which is a deterministic Markov policy? Making some assumptions with regards to measurable selections, we can find, using dynamic programming, the optimal policy.
Theorem 5: Define the real-valued functions JN,JN−1,…,J0J_N, J_{N-1}, \ldots, J_0JN​,JN−1​,…,J0​﻿ on S\mathcal SS﻿ inductively as follows: for each x∈Sx \in \mathcal Sx∈S﻿,
JN(x):=rN(x)Jn(x):=sup⁡{r(x,a)+∫SJn+1(y)κ((x,a),dy)  ∣  a∈α(x)},n=N−1,N−2,…,0.\begin{align*} J_N(x) &:= r_N(x) \\ J_n(x) &:= \sup \left\{\left. r(x,a) + \int_{\mathcal S} J_{n+1}(y) \kappa((x,a), \mathrm{d}y) \; \right\vert \; a \in \alpha(x) \right\}, \quad n = N-1, N-2, \ldots, 0. \end{align*}JN​(x)Jn​(x)​:=rN​(x):=sup{r(x,a)+∫S​Jn+1​(y)κ((x,a),dy)∣∣​a∈α(x)},n=N−1,N−2,…,0.​
Suppose that these functions are measurable and that, for each n=0,…,N−1n = 0, \ldots, N-1n=0,…,N−1﻿, there exists a measurable selector fn ⁣:S→Af_n \colon \mathcal S \to \mathcal Afn​:S→A﻿ satisfying fn(x)∈α(x)f_n(x) \in \alpha(x)fn​(x)∈α(x)﻿ for all x∈Sx \in \mathcal Sx∈S﻿ (or equivalently ⟦f⟧⊆⟦α⟧\llbracket f \rrbracket \subseteq \llbracket \alpha \rrbracket[[f]]⊆[[α]]﻿), and that fn(x)f_n(x)fn​(x)﻿ attains the maximum in the supremum above, i.e.,
Jn(x)=r(x,fn(x))+∫SJn+1(y)κ((x,fn(x)),dy),∀ x∈S, n=0,…,N−1.J_n(x) = r(x,f_n(x)) + \int_{\mathcal S} J_{n+1}(y) \kappa((x, f_n(x)), \mathrm{d}y), \quad \forall \, x \in \mathcal S,\, n = 0, \ldots, N-1.Jn​(x)=r(x,fn​(x))+∫S​Jn+1​(y)κ((x,fn​(x)),dy),∀x∈S,n=0,…,N−1.
Then the deterministic Markov policy π∗:=(f0,…,fN−1)\pi^* := (f_0, \ldots, f_{N-1})π∗:=(f0​,…,fN−1​)﻿ is optimal, and the value function J∗J^*J∗﻿ equals J0.J_0.J0​.﻿
Proof:
Let π=(π0,…,πN−1)∈Π\pi = (\pi_0, \ldots, \pi_{N-1}) \in \Piπ=(π0​,…,πN−1​)∈Π﻿ be an arbitrary policy, and for n=0,…,N−1n = 0, \ldots, N-1n=0,…,N−1﻿ let Rn(π,x)R_n(\pi, x)Rn​(π,x)﻿ be the corresponding expected total cost from time nnn﻿ to the terminal time NNN﻿, given that Xn=xX_n = xXn​=x﻿. That is,
Rn(π,x):=Exπ[r(x,An)+∑m=n+1N−1r(Xm,Am)+rN(XN)].(4)R_n(\pi, x) := \mathbb{E}_x^\pi \left[ r(x, A_n) + \sum_{m=n+1}^{N-1} r(X_m, A_m) + r_N(X_N) \right]. \tag{4}Rn​(π,x):=Exπ​[r(x,An​)+m=n+1∑N−1​r(Xm​,Am​)+rN​(XN​)].(4)
Also let RN(π,x):=rN(x).R_N(\pi, x) := r_N(x).RN​(π,x):=rN​(x).﻿ Note that we have
R0(π,x)=J(π,x).R_0(\pi, x) = J(\pi, x).R0​(π,x)=J(π,x).
To prove the theorem it is sufficient to show that, for all x∈Sx \in \mathcal Sx∈S﻿ and n=0,…,Nn = 0, \ldots, Nn=0,…,N﻿,
Rn(π,x)≤Jn(x) and Rn(π∗,x)=Jn(x).(5)\tag{5} R_n(\pi, x) \le J_n(x) \text{ and } R_n(\pi^*, x) = J_n(x). Rn​(π,x)≤Jn​(x) and Rn​(π∗,x)=Jn​(x).(5)
(5) holds for n=Nn = Nn=N﻿ by definition. We proceed by induction in the backward direction. Assume that for some k∈{N−1,…,0}k \in \{N-1, \ldots, 0\}k∈{N−1,…,0}﻿,
Rk+1(π,x)≤Jk+1(x),∀ x∈S.R_{k+1}(\pi, x) \le J_{k+1}(x), \quad \forall \, x \in S. Rk+1​(π,x)≤Jk+1​(x),∀x∈S.
Then by (4), (C2) and (C3),
Rk(π,x)=Exπ[r(x,Ak)+∑m=k+1N−1r(Xm,Am)+rN(XN)]=∫A[r(x,a)+∫SRk+1(π,y)κ((x,a),dy)]πk(x,da)≤∫A[r(x,a)+∫SJk+1(y)κ((x,a),dy)]πk(x,da)≤sup⁡{r(x,a)+∫SJk+1(y)κ((x,a),dy)  ∣  a∈α(x)}=Jk(x).(6)\begin{align*} \tag{6} R_k(\pi, x) &= \mathbb{E}_x^\pi \left[ r(x, A_k) + \sum_{m=k+1}^{N-1} r(X_m, A_m) + r_N(X_N) \right] \\ &= \int_{\mathcal A} \left[ r(x,a) + \int_{\mathcal S} R_{k+1}(\pi, y) \kappa((x,a), \mathrm{d}y) \right] \pi_k(x, \mathrm{d}a) \\ &\le \int_{\mathcal A} \left[ r(x,a) + \int_{\mathcal S} J_{k+1}(y) \kappa((x,a), \mathrm{d}y) \right] \pi_k(x, \mathrm{d}a) \\ &\le \sup \left\{\left. r(x,a) + \int_{S} J_{k+1}(y) \kappa((x,a), \mathrm{d}y) \; \right\vert \; a \in \alpha(x) \right\} \\ &= J_k(x). \end{align*}Rk​(π,x)​=Exπ​[r(x,Ak​)+m=k+1∑N−1​r(Xm​,Am​)+rN​(XN​)]=∫A​[r(x,a)+∫S​Rk+1​(π,y)κ((x,a),dy)]πk​(x,da)≤∫A​[r(x,a)+∫S​Jk+1​(y)κ((x,a),dy)]πk​(x,da)≤sup{r(x,a)+∫S​Jk+1​(y)κ((x,a),dy)∣∣​a∈α(x)}=Jk​(x).​(6)
This proves the first claim in (5) for all n=0,…,N.n = 0, \ldots, N.n=0,…,N.﻿ Proceeding in a similar manner for π=π∗\pi = \pi^*π=π∗﻿, where the first inequality in (6) becomes an equality by the induction hypothesis, and the second inequality in (6) becomes an equality by the structure of π∗\pi^*π∗﻿, we conclude the second claim in (5) also. □\square□﻿
Measurable Selections
We assumed in the statement of the theorem above
Reinforcement Learning
In RL, the transition law κ\kappaκ﻿ and the reward function rrr﻿ are unknown, and must be “discovered” by appropriate exploration. This induces the exploration/exploitation dilemma.
The reward function may be zero for all n=0,…,N−1n = 0, \ldots, N-1n=0,…,N−1﻿, and only the terminal cost might be giving us feedback. This sharpens the credit assignment problem.
The state may also not be directly observable, and thus a filtering problem gets added on top.
